block.p: NEW YORK CITY
NEW YORK CITY
Schools Get Grants for Arts

The Annenberg Foundation is planning a $36 million program to revitalize arts education in New York City's public schools, making it a systematic part of the curriculum from kindergarten through high school. [Page A1.]
Giuliani Rejects 2 Judges

Overturning a longstanding precedent, Mayor Giuliani has rejected the recommendations of his own judicial screening panel and decided not to reappoint two Brooklyn Criminal Court judges to full terms. [B1.]
Harlem Store Owners Harassed
At least 10 white or Korean store owners in Harlem have received racially charged threats since the arson attack on Freddy's clothing store that left eight people dead, police officials said. [B1.]
So, How Else to Measure Snow?

How do we know they're right when they say that seven and a half inches of snow fell in Central Park? By using computers or other gizmos? Make no mistake. The snow is measured by a meteorologist with a ruler. NYC by Clyde Haberman. [B1.]
Bronx Suspect Admits Fire Plot
The man accused of shooting five people to death in a Bronx shoe store has told the police that he planned to burn the business down, a senior police investigator said. [B3.]
Effects of a Taxi Fare Increase
New York City's plan to raise taxi fares would fall more heavily on riders taking short, fast trips than on those making long, slow ones. [B6.]
Subway Attacker Identified?

The Brooklyn District Attorney said investigators believe they know who ignited the flammable liquid that killed a token clerk in Brooklyn, but had not developed sufficient evidence to charge him. [B6.]
Ruling on Bias Compensation

In a 19-year-old case originally brought by 124 women police officers in New York City, the state's highest court ruled 4 to 3 that public employees who are discrimination victims have the same right to retroactive compensation as those who work for private companies. [B7.] REGION
A Wonderland Lights Hartford

The G. Fox & Company department store, a Hartford institution that closed three years ago, has attracted more than 70,000 people since Thanksgiving to a giant display called Winter Wonderland, a six-floor smorgasbord of Christmas displays, children's attractions and December kitsch set up in the otherwise vacant building to benefit charities. [B1.]
Pataki Gets Police Bill

Racing an end-of-the-year deadline and ignoring the objections of Mayor Giuliani, the State Legislature has sent Governor Pataki a bill that would require automatic promotions for hundreds of New York City police sergeants and lieutenants. [B5.]
Air Travel Returns to Normal
Airlines returned to their normal operations after two days of delays caused by snow and wind. Investigators said they saw no reason for a runway mishap at Kennedy. [B5.]
Court Says Primary Rules Legal

In a ruling that benefits Senator Bob Dole's candidacy for the Presidential nomination, a Federal appeals court said that the State Republican Party's complex rules for electing Presidential delegates were constitutional. [B5.]
Local Family Survives Air Crash

Several members of a New Jersey family apparently survived the crash of a jetliner in Colombia, but other passengers from the New York region were still unaccounted for. This week's snowstorms, which disrupted flights out of New York-area airports, may have saved the lives of some passengers who had planned to board the American Airlines jet. International report. [A14.]
Charter-School Subsidies Gain

New Jersey would become the 20th state to allow state-chartered schools that are publicly financed but privately operated in a bill approved by the State Senate 25 to 10. In the last five years, almost 200 charter schools have opened around the country: in shopping centers, a former grocery store and in a low-income housing project. [B4.]
First Arrest Under a New Law
An Ohio man has been arrested for harassing his ex-wife in New Jersey, the first man in the country to face charges under a year-old Federal law. [B6.]
State to Share Medicaid Costs

New York State's highest court has ruled that the state must make millions of dollars in retroactive payments to doctors, hospitals and ambulance companies for service to elderly and poor patients under its Medicaid program. [B7.]
